stream_context.summary: Kaze returns from off-stream work (including a massive "Only Up 64" SimpleFlips competition level) and continues Return to Yoshi’s Island development: showcases new collision stability, prototypes a seesaw gag where a Goomba gets squished after a breakable-box trigger, and does real-N64 performance testing/optimization (backface culling, triangle trimming). A major technical detour occurs when an N64 crash reveals a division-by-zero caused by compiler delay-slot scheduling, forcing a code restructure and a reminder of the pain of maintaining two repos (RTYI + Only Up 64).
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete N64 performance numbers, an optimization decision (N64-only backface culling), and a compiler/delay-slot division-by-zero incident that reveals real constraints of N64-targeted C/ASM-era behavior and multi-repo maintenance costs.

findings.summary: Kaze implemented/merged collision-system improvements that make Mario’s interaction with ceilings and complex surfaces significantly more stable than vanilla SM64, and he highlights that certain triangle layouts that are "deadly" in vanilla now behave predictably.

He prototypes a scripted/"faked physics" seesaw set piece: a Goomba stands on a plank, the player breaks a box to trigger the plank’s fall/rotation, and the intended payoff is the Goomba being slowly squished in a comedic, readable way.
findings.quote: We only need to fake it well enough that no one notices that it's fake.

findings.summary: Real-N64 testing reveals performance bottlenecks in a large factory-like area; he measures worst-case views dropping to ~19–22 FPS and uses those readings to decide which optimizations are acceptable for console targets.

A simple rendering change—enabling backface culling on select materials—raises worst-case N64 performance to ~25–29 FPS, which Kaze deems playable. He prefers the non-culled look on emulator but accepts culling on hardware.

He quantifies geometry scale: the tested area shows ~13,000 triangles with text enabled and ~6,000 without the text layer; performance issues are tied to worst-case views with many non-backface-culled triangles filling the screen.

He identifies additional optimization opportunities beyond culling: deleting unseen underside polygons, removing redundant transform nodes (extra matrix multiply per frame), and building a collision map to reduce collision-triangle processing cost.

While testing on N64 he hits a floating point exception in ClipMario. Root cause: division by zero where the value becomes 0, and critically, the compiler schedules the division into a branch delay slot so it executes even when the branch should avoid it; he restructures code to prevent unconditional divide-by-zero.
findings.quote: The compiler decided... to pipeline the division into the delay slot of my branch. So that no matter what happens, I always divide by 0.

findings.summary: Maintaining two separate codebases (RTYI and Only Up 64) creates immediate tech-debt: a bug fix in shared/duplicated code must be applied in both repos, reinforcing his dislike of parallel repos for similar tech.
findings.quote: This is why I hate having two repos, because now I need to fix this in two places at once.

findings.summary: RTYI targets Expansion Pak usage; Kaze notes the game currently does not fit within 4MB, and fitting it would require significant engineering work (separate loading of areas/code) that he sees as poor value for the payoff.

The factory/oil-area lore shifted over time: originally conceived as "Bozo’s Fleet Factory," it evolved into more of a refueling/utility location, and the story emphasis may be on Bozo reacting to Mario destroying airships rather than showing many airships in-level.
Kaze expresses a preference for discrete worlds connected through an overworld rather than heavy inter-world interconnection (citing Banjo-Tooie style backtracking as undesirable).
findings.quote: I think it's nicer if the worlds are separate and the interconnectedness comes from the overworld alone.

findings.summary: Zeina has already produced animations for at least one key NPC/enemy (Kaze references "this guy" being mostly animated), enabling Kaze to plan upcoming behavior/mission work that depends on animation readiness (e.g., an "overseer" character still needs animations).
Badub (composer) has been absent for a while; Kaze is uncertain when to expect new music and reiterates that full sound design will happen late once content and sound-slot budgets are clear.

Kaze explains streaming strategy: he streams dev on the Kaze Clips channel to avoid harming the main-channel algorithm and to keep the audience primarily game-focused. Financially, he says YouTube is barely profitable lately, especially after a sponsorship deal ended.
findings.quote: I just care about making a good game.

findings.summary: He mentions a recent playtest of Course 2 and that changes were made based on it, implying iterative level tuning and external feedback cycles continuing in parallel with new feature work.

biobak.summary: Biobak reacts positively to Kaze’s approach of "real physics" vs faked animation for the seesaw gag, reinforcing the intended illusion-first philosophy for set pieces.

badub.summary: Kaze notes Badub has been missing in attendance, affecting expectations for a planned song/music contribution in the near term.
Kaze indicates sound design will be handled late in production (and agrees in principle to involve Badub), once available sound slots and final needs are known.

zeina.summary: Kaze credits Zeina with making (most of) the animations for a character/enemy he’s checking, and later notes she’s out with friends during the stream, implying asynchronous collaboration and dependency on her animation pipeline.

findings.summary: Lilaa provides feedback during the seesaw/Goomba-squish implementation (suggesting caution if an issue isn’t fixed), and is also referenced in ongoing banter about tools/choices; Kaze engages but keeps design/engineering direction.
findings.quote: Without fixing the issue it might be a good idea.

findings.summary: Kaze addresses CockyDev directly about modifying ClipMario code again; this indicates others on the project/community review or rely on that movement/clipping code and notice changes.
A viewer suggests reporting the compiler delay-slot divide-by-zero behavior to EZSpy; Kaze doubts there’s much they can do, underscoring how low-level/toolchain behaviors constrain the project.

key_stories.title: Building a comedic seesaw set piece (Goomba squish gag)
key_stories.summary: Kaze designs a small narrative interaction: the player breaks a box, the seesaw tips, and the Goomba ends up pinned/squished for comedic payoff. He iterates on predictability, timing, and how to keep the illusion believable without full physics simulation.
key_stories.challenge: Making the sequence readable and deterministic (trigger clarity, controlled rotation speed, preventing weird clipping), while keeping implementation simple enough for N64 constraints.
key_stories.process: He prototypes the behavior, adjusts rotation/acceleration, adds constraints/safes to prevent the Goomba from ending up on top or phasing through, and considers audio cues and future polish (sound design later).
key_stories.outcome: A working version produces a strong final tableau (plank pinning the Goomba), but squish detection/behavior still needs refinement; next steps include detaching logic and polishing interactions.
key_stories.key_quote: We only need to fake it well enough that no one notices that it's fake.

key_stories.title: N64 performance reality check and the backface-culling decision
key_stories.summary: Kaze runs the large factory/oil area on real N64 and finds worst-case angles drop below target framerate. He tests a quick fix—backface culling on certain materials—and sees a major improvement, then decides to apply it primarily for N64 while preserving the preferred look on emulator.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining acceptable framerate on real hardware in a visually dense, large-scale space with many visible triangles and long sightlines.
key_stories.process: He measures FPS at worst viewpoints, inspects triangle counts, tests toggling backface culling, considers triangle deletion for unseen undersides, and notes future gains from collision map generation and trimming unnecessary nodes.
key_stories.outcome: Backface culling raises worst-case performance to ~25–29 FPS, which he accepts as playable; he plans further optimization by removing unseen geometry and improving collision processing.

key_stories.title: The divide-by-zero that wasn’t in the code (compiler delay slot scheduling)
key_stories.summary: During N64 testing, the game throws a floating point exception in ClipMario. Kaze initially adds a guard (epsilon) but discovers the compiler moved the division into a branch delay slot, making the divide execute regardless; he then restructures code to force safe scheduling.
key_stories.challenge: A hardware-only crash caused by toolchain/codegen behavior rather than an obvious logic mistake, compounded by emulator inaccuracy masking the issue.
key_stories.process: He reproduces on N64, traces to ClipMario, identifies the 0 divisor, attempts a small fix, then inspects generated behavior and rewrites the computation ordering to avoid unconditional division.
key_stories.outcome: He corrects the scheduling hazard and notes he must apply the fix to both RTYI and Only Up 64 repos, reinforcing how hardware tests catch issues emulators miss.
key_stories.key_quote: That is not a bug in the code. That is not my fault.

key_stories.title: Channel strategy and the cost of staying independent
key_stories.summary: Kaze explains why development streams live on Kaze Clips rather than the main channel: to protect the main-channel algorithm and keep a dedicated audience that actually cares about the game. He also shares that YouTube revenue is thin, especially after a sponsorship deal ended, affecting how much he can pay contributors.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing visibility and sustainability with creative focus, without turning dev streams into algorithm-driven content.
key_stories.process: He chooses a smaller channel for dev streams, avoids pushing streams to the main audience, and acknowledges financial constraints post-sponsorship while continuing development.
key_stories.outcome: A clearer separation between game-dev community streams and broader content, but with reduced revenue and viewership compared to prior Twitch streaming.
key_stories.key_quote: I can just upload whatever the fuck I want and I don't really care if that fucks my algorithm or not.
